column2: It was very well for Margaret that the extreme quiet of the Harley Street house, during Edith's recovery from her confinement, gave her the natural rest which she needed.
column3: It was very well for Margaret that the extreme quiet of the Harley Street house, during Edith's recovery from her confinement, gave her the natural rest which she needed.

column2: It gave her time to comprehend the sudden change which had taken place in her circumstances within the last two months.
column3: It gave her time to comprehend the sudden change which had taken place in her circumstances within the last two months.

column2: She found herself at once an inmate of a luxurious house, where the bare knowledge of the existence of every trouble or care seemed scarcely to have penetrated.
column3: She found herself at once an inmate of a luxurious house, where the bare knowledge of the existence of every trouble or care seemed scarcely to have penetrated.

column2: The wheels of the machinery of daily life were well oiled, and went along with delicious smoothness.
column3: The wheels of the machinery of daily life were well oiled, and went along with delicious smoothness.

column2: Mrs. Shaw and Edith could hardly make enough of Margaret, on her return to what they persisted in calling her home.

column2: And she felt that it was almost ungrateful in her to have a secret feeling that the Helstone vicarage--nay, even the poor little house at Milton, with her anxious father and her invalid mother, and all the small household cares of comparative poverty, composed her idea of home.

column2: Edith was impatient to get well, in order to fill Margaret's bed-room with all the soft comforts, and pretty nick-knacks, with which her own abounded.
column3: Edith was impatient to get well, in order to fill Margaret's bed room with all the soft comforts, and pretty nick knacks, with which her own abounded.

column2: Captain Lennox was easy, kind, and gentlemanly; sate with his wife in her dressing-room an hour or two every day; played with his little boy for another hour, and lounged away the rest of his time at his club, when he was not engaged out to dinner. Just before Margaret had recovered from her necessity for quiet and repose--before she had begun to feel her life wanting and dull--Edith came down-stairs and resumed her usual part in the household; and Margaret fell into the old habit of watching, and admiring, and ministering to her cousin.

column2: The course of Margaret's day was this; a quiet hour or two before a late breakfast; an unpunctual meal, lazily eaten by weary and half-awake people, but yet at which, in all its dragged-out length, she was expected to be present, because, directly afterwards, came a discussion of plans, at which, although they none of them concerned her, she was expected to give her sympathy, if she could not assist with her advice; an endless number of notes to write, which Edith invariably left to her, with many caressing compliments as to her eloquence du billet; a little play with Sholto as he returned from his morning's walk; besides the care of the children during the servants' dinner; a drive or callers; and some dinner or morning engagement for her aunt and cousins, which left Margaret free, it is true, but rather wearied with the inactivity of the day, coming upon depressed spirits and delicate health.

column2: But it was only here and there that the name came in, or any Milton name, indeed; and Margaret was sitting one evening, all alone in the Lennoxes's drawing-room, not reading Dixon's letters, which yet she held in her hand, but thinking over them, and recalling the days which had been, and picturing the busy life out of which her own had been taken and never missed; wondering if all went on in that whirl just as if she and her father had never been; questioning within herself, if no one in all the crowd missed her, (not Higgins, she was not thinking of him,) when, suddenly, Mr. Bell was announced; and Margaret hurried the letters into her work-basket, and started up, blushing as if she had been doing some guilty thing.

column2: Then Mr. Lennox said, addressing himself to Margaret, 'I suppose as Mr. Bell is now acquainted with all the circumstances attending your brother's unfortunate dilemma, I cannot do better than inform him exactly how the research into the evidence we once hoped to produce in his favour stands at present.

column2: So, if he will do me the honour to breakfast with me to-morrow, we will go over the names of these missing gentry.'
column3: So, if he will do me the honour to breakfast with me to morrow, we will go over the names of these missing gentry.'

column2: 'I should like to hear all the particulars, if I may.
column3: 'I should like to hear all the particulars, if I may.

column2: Cannot you come here?
column3: Cannot you come here?

column2: I dare not ask you both to breakfast, though I am sure you would be welcome.
column3: I dare not ask you both to breakfast, though I am sure you would be welcome.

column2: But let me know all I can about Frederick, even though there may be no hope at present.'
column3: But let me know all I can about Frederick, even though there may be no hope at present.'

column2: 'I have an engagement at half-past eleven.
column3: 'I have an engagement at half past eleven.

column2: But I will certainly come if you wish it,' replied Mr. Lennox, with a little afterthought of extreme willingness, which made Margaret shrink into herself, and almost wish that she had not proposed her natural request.
column3: But I will certainly come if you wish it,' replied mr Lennox, with a little afterthought of extreme willingness, which made Margaret shrink into herself, and almost wish that she had not proposed her natural request.

column2: Mr. Bell got up and looked around him for his hat, which had been removed to make room for tea.
column3: mr Bell got up and looked around him for his hat, which had been removed to make room for tea.

column2: 'Well!' said he, 'I don't know what Mr. Lennox is inclined to do, but I'm disposed to be moving off homewards.
column3: 'Well!' said he, 'I don't know what mr Lennox is inclined to do, but I'm disposed to be moving off homewards.

column2: I've been a journey to-day, and journeys begin to tell upon my sixty and odd years.'
column3: I've been a journey to day, and journeys begin to tell upon my sixty and odd years.'

column2: 'I believe I shall stay and see my brother and sister,' said Mr. Lennox, making no movement of departure.
column3: 'I believe I shall stay and see my brother and sister,' said mr Lennox, making no movement of departure.

column2: Margaret was seized with a shy awkward dread of being left alone with him.
column3: Margaret was seized with a shy awkward dread of being left alone with him.

column2: The scene on the little terrace in the Helstone garden was so present to her, that she could hardly help believing it was so with him.
column3: The scene on the little terrace in the Helstone garden was so present to her, that she could hardly help believing it was so with him.

column2: 'Don't go yet, please, Mr. Bell,' said she, hastily.
column3: 'Don't go yet, please, mr Bell,' said she, hastily.

column2: 'I want you to see Edith; and I want Edith to know you.
column3: 'I want you to see Edith; and I want Edith to know you.

column2: Please!' said she, laying a light but determined hand on his arm.
column3: Please!' said she, laying a light but determined hand on his arm.

column2: He looked at her, and saw the confusion stirring in her countenance; he sate down again, as if her little touch had been possessed of resistless strength.
column3: He looked at her, and saw the confusion stirring in her countenance; he sate down again, as if her little touch had been possessed of resistless strength.

column2: 'You see how she overpowers me, Mr. Lennox,' said he.
column3: 'You see how she overpowers me, mr Lennox,' said he.

column2: 'And I hope you noticed the happy choice of her expressions; she wants me to "see" this cousin Edith, who, I am told, is a great beauty; but she has the honesty to change her word when she comes to me--Mrs.
column3: 'And I hope you noticed the happy choice of her expressions; she wants me to "see" this cousin Edith, who, I am told, is a great beauty; but she has the honesty to change her word when she comes to me-mrs

column2: Lennox is to "know" me.
column3: Lennox is to "know" me.

column2: I suppose I am not much to "see," eh, Margaret?'
column3: I suppose I am not much to "see," eh, Margaret?'

column2: He joked, to give her time to recover from the slight flutter which he had detected in her manner on his proposal to leave; and she caught the tone, and threw the ball back.
column3: He joked, to give her time to recover from the slight flutter which he had detected in her manner on his proposal to leave; and she caught the tone, and threw the ball back.

column2: Mr. Lennox wondered how his brother, the Captain, could have reported her as having lost all her good looks.
column3: mr Lennox wondered how his brother, the Captain, could have reported her as having lost all her good looks.

column2: To be sure, in her quiet black dress, she was a contrast to Edith, dancing in her white crape mourning, and long floating golden hair, all softness and glitter.
column3: To be sure, in her quiet black dress, she was a contrast to Edith, dancing in her white crape mourning, and long floating golden hair, all softness and glitter.

column2: She dimpled and blushed most becomingly when introduced to Mr. Bell, conscious that she had her reputation as a beauty to keep up, and that it would not do to have a Mordecai refusing to worship and admire, even in the shape of an old Fellow of a College, which nobody had ever heard of.
column3: She dimpled and blushed most becomingly when introduced to mr Bell, conscious that she had her reputation as a beauty to keep up, and that it would not do to have a Mordecai refusing to worship and admire, even in the shape of an old Fellow of a College, which nobody had ever heard of.

column2: Mrs. Shaw and Captain Lennox, each in their separate way, gave Mr. Bell a kind and sincere welcome, winning him over to like them almost in spite of himself, especially when he saw how naturally Margaret took her place as sister and daughter of the house.
column3: mrs Shaw and Captain Lennox, each in their separate way, gave mr Bell a kind and sincere welcome, winning him over to like them almost in spite of himself, especially when he saw how naturally Margaret took her place as sister and daughter of the house.

column2: 'What a shame that we were not at home to receive you,' said Edith. 'You, too, Henry! though I don't know that we should have stayed at home for you.
column3: 'What a shame that we were not at home to receive you,' said Edith. 'You, too, Henry! though I don't know that we should have stayed at home for you.

column2: And for Mr. Bell! for Margaret's Mr. Bell---- '
column3: And for mr Bell! for Margaret's mr Bell---- '

column2: 'There is no knowing what sacrifices you would not have made,' said her brother-in-law. 'Even a dinner-party! and the delight of wearing this very becoming dress.'
column3: 'There is no knowing what sacrifices you would not have made,' said her brother in law. 'Even a dinner party! and the delight of wearing this very becoming dress.'

column2: Edith did not know whether to frown or to smile.
column3: Edith did not know whether to frown or to smile.

column2: But it did not suit Mr. Lennox to drive her to the first of these alternatives; so he went on.
column3: But it did not suit mr Lennox to drive her to the first of these alternatives; so he went on.

column2: 'Will you show your readiness to make sacrifices to-morrow morning, first by asking me to breakfast, to meet Mr. Bell, and secondly, by being so kind as to order it at half-past nine, instead of ten o'clock? I have some letters and papers that I want to show to Miss Hale and Mr. Bell.'
column3: 'Will you show your readiness to make sacrifices to morrow morning, first by asking me to breakfast, to meet mr Bell, and secondly, by being so kind as to order it at half past nine, instead of ten o'clock? I have some letters and papers that I want to show to Miss Hale and mr Bell.'

column2: 'I hope Mr. Bell will make our house his own during his stay in London,' said Captain Lennox. 'I am only so sorry we cannot offer him a bed-room.'
column3: 'I hope mr Bell will make our house his own during his stay in London,' said Captain Lennox. 'I am only so sorry we cannot offer him a bed room.'

column2: 'Thank you.
column3: 'Thank you.

column2: I am much obliged to you.
column3: I am much obliged to you.

column2: You would only think me a churl if you had, for I should decline it, I believe, in spite of all the temptations of such agreeable company,' said Mr. Bell, bowing all round, and secretly congratulating himself on the neat turn he had given to his sentence, which, if put into plain language, would have been more to this effect: 'I couldn't stand the restraints of such a proper-behaved and civil-spoken set of people as these are: it would be like meat without salt.
column3: You would only think me a churl if you had, for I should decline it, I believe, in spite of all the temptations of such agreeable company,' said mr Bell, bowing all round, and secretly congratulating himself on the neat turn he had given to his sentence, which, if put into plain language, would have been more to this effect: 'I couldn't stand the restraints of such a proper behaved and civil spoken set of people as these are: it would be like meat without salt.

column2: I'm thankful they haven't a bed.
column3: I'm thankful they haven't a bed.

column2: And how well I rounded my sentence!
column3: And how well I rounded my sentence!

column2: I am absolutely catching the trick of good manners.'
column3: I am absolutely catching the trick of good manners.'

column2: His self-satisfaction lasted him till he was fairly out in the streets, walking side by side with Henry Lennox.
column3: His self satisfaction lasted him till he was fairly out in the streets, walking side by side with Henry Lennox.

column2: Here he suddenly remembered Margaret's little look of entreaty as she urged him to stay longer, and he also recollected a few hints given him long ago by an acquaintance of Mr. Lennox's, as to his admiration of Margaret.
column3: Here he suddenly remembered Margaret's little look of entreaty as she urged him to stay longer, and he also recollected a few hints given him long ago by an acquaintance of mr Lennox's, as to his admiration of Margaret.

column2: It gave a new direction to his thoughts.

column2: 'You have known Miss Hale for a long time, I believe. How do you think her looking?
column3: 'You have known Miss Hale for a long time, I believe. How do you think her looking?

column2: She strikes me as pale and ill.'
column3: She strikes me as pale and ill.'

column2: 'I thought her looking remarkably well.
column3: 'I thought her looking remarkably well.

column2: Perhaps not when I first came in--now I think of it.
column3: Perhaps not when I first came in-now I think of it.

column2: But certainly, when she grew animated, she looked as well as ever I saw her do.'
column3: But certainly, when she grew animated, she looked as well as ever I saw her do.'

column2: 'She has had a great deal to go through,' said Mr. Bell.
column3: 'She has had a great deal to go through,' said mr Bell.

column2: 'Yes!
column3: 'Yes!

column2: I have been sorry to hear of all she has had to bear; not merely the common and universal sorrow arising from death, but all the annoyance which her father's conduct must have caused her, and then----'
column3: I have been sorry to hear of all she has had to bear; not merely the common and universal sorrow arising from death, but all the annoyance which her father's conduct must have caused her, and then----'

column2: 'Her father's conduct!' said Mr. Bell, in an accent of surprise.
column3: 'Her father's conduct!' said mr Bell, in an accent of surprise.

column2: 'You must have heard some wrong statement.
column3: 'You must have heard some wrong statement.

column2: He behaved in the most conscientious manner.
column3: He behaved in the most conscientious manner.

column2: He showed more resolute strength than I should ever have given him credit for formerly.'
column3: He showed more resolute strength than I should ever have given him credit for formerly.'

column2: 'Perhaps I have been wrongly informed.
column3: 'Perhaps I have been wrongly informed.

column2: But I have been told, by his successor in the living--a clever, sensible man, and a thoroughly active clergyman--that there was no call upon Mr. Hale to do what he did, relinquish the living, and throw himself and his family on the tender mercies of private teaching in a manufacturing town; the bishop had offered him another living, it is true, but if he had come to entertain certain doubts, he could have remained where he was, and so had no occasion to resign.
column3: But I have been told, by his successor in the living-a clever, sensible man, and a thoroughly active clergyman-that there was no call upon mr Hale to do what he did, relinquish the living, and throw himself and his family on the tender mercies of private teaching in a manufacturing town; the bishop had offered him another living, it is true, but if he had come to entertain certain doubts, he could have remained where he was, and so had no occasion to resign.

column2: But the truth is, these country clergymen live such isolated lives--isolated, I mean, from all intercourse with men of equal cultivation with themselves, by whose minds they might regulate their own, and discover when they were going either too fast or too slow--that they are very apt to disturb themselves with imaginary doubts as to the articles of faith, and throw up certain opportunities of doing good for very uncertain fancies of their own.'
column3: But the truth is, these country clergymen live such isolated lives-isolated, I mean, from all intercourse with men of equal cultivation with themselves, by whose minds they might regulate their own, and discover when they were going either too fast or too slow-that they are very apt to disturb themselves with imaginary doubts as to the articles of faith, and throw up certain opportunities of doing good for very uncertain fancies of their own.'

column2: 'I differ from you.
column3: 'I differ from you.

column2: I do not think they are very apt to do as my poor friend Hale did.' Mr. Bell was inwardly chafing.
column3: I do not think they are very apt to do as my poor friend Hale did.' mr Bell was inwardly chafing.

column2: 'Perhaps I used too general an expression, in saying "very apt." But certainly, their lives are such as very often to produce either inordinate self-sufficiency, or a morbid state of conscience,' replied Mr. Lennox with perfect coolness.
column3: 'Perhaps I used too general an expression, in saying "very apartment" But certainly, their lives are such as very often to produce either inordinate self sufficiency, or a morbid state of conscience,' replied mr Lennox with perfect coolness.

column2: 'You don't meet with any self-sufficiency among the lawyers, for instance?' asked Mr. Bell. 'And seldom, I imagine, any cases of morbid conscience.' He was becoming more and more vexed, and forgetting his lately-caught trick of good manners.
column3: 'You don't meet with any self sufficiency among the lawyers, for instance?' asked mr Bell. 'And seldom, I imagine, any cases of morbid conscience.' He was becoming more and more vexed, and forgetting his lately caught trick of good manners.

column2: Mr. Lennox saw now that he had annoyed his companion; and as he had talked pretty much for the sake of saying something, and so passing the time while their road lay together, he was very indifferent as to the exact side he took upon the question, and quietly came round by saying: 'To be sure, there is something fine in a man of Mr. Hale's age leaving his home of twenty years, and giving up all settled habits, for an idea which was probably erroneous--but that does not matter--an untangible thought.

column2: One cannot help admiring him, with a mixture of pity in one's admiration, something like what one feels for Don Quixote.

column2: Such a gentleman as he was too!

column2: I shall never forget the refined and simple hospitality he showed to me that last day at Helstone.'
column3: I shall never forget the refined and simple hospitality he showed to me that last day at Helstone.'

column2: Only half mollified, and yet anxious, in order to lull certain qualms of his own conscience, to believe that Mr. Hale's conduct had a tinge of Quixotism in it, Mr. Bell growled out--'Aye!

column2: And you don't know Milton. Such a change from Helstone!

column2: It is years since I have been at Helstone--but I'll answer for it, it is standing there yet--every stick and every stone as it has done for the last century, while Milton!
column3: It is years since I have been at Helstone-but I'll answer for it, it is standing there yet-every stick and every stone as it has done for the last century, while Milton!

column2: I go there every four or five years--and I was born there--yet I do assure you, I often lose my way--aye, among the very piles of warehouses that are built upon my father's orchard.

column2: Do we part here?
column3: Do we part here?

column2: Well, good night, sir; I suppose we shall meet in Harley Street to-morrow morning.'
column3: Well, good night, sir; I suppose we shall meet in Harley Street to morrow morning.'
